flawed_nl_solution:
The sum of the ratios representing the amount of money the three has is 4+5+6=<<4+5+6=13>>13
If the total amount of money they have is $75, the amount of money Cara has represented by the fraction 4/13 is 4/13*$75=$300/13<<4/13*75=300/13>>300/13
Similarly, the amount of money Janet has represented by the fraction 5/13 of the total ratio is 5/13*$75=$375/13<<5/13*75=375/13>>375/13
Combined, Cara and Janet have $300/13+375/13=$675/13<<300/13+375/13=675/13>>675/13
If Cara and Janet buy goods worth $675/13 and sells them at 80% of the buying price, the selling price of the goods will be 80/100*$675/13=$540/13<<675/13*80/100=540/13>>540/13
Since they bought the goods at $675/13 and sold them at $540/13, Janet and Cara would run at a loss of $675/13-$540/13=$135/13<<675/13-540/13=135/13>>135/13
#### 135/13

error_details.explanation: The result of this computation should be 15, not 13. This appears to be a minor miscalculation.
